Russell_Smith_(singer):
{{Short description|American singer-songwriter (1949–2019)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Russell Smith | image = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Howard Russell Smith | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1949|06|17}} | birth_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2019|7|12|1949|06|17}} | death_place = [[Franklin, Tennessee]], U.S. | genre = Country, rock | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1972–2019 | label = {{hlist|[[Capitol Records|Capitol]]|[[Epic Records|Epic]]|Muscle Shoals}} | past_member_of = {{hlist|[[The Amazing Rhythm Aces]]|[[Run C&W]]}} | website = }} '''Howard Russell Smith''' (June 17, 1949 – July 12, 2019) was an American singer and songwriter. He was the lead singer of the groups [[The Amazing Rhythm Aces]] and [[Run C&W]]. As a solo artist, he released four studio albums and charted five singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles]] chart between 1984 and 1989. ==Early life and career== Smith was born in [[Nashville]] and grew up in [[Lafayette, Tennessee]]. [[The Amazing Rhythm Aces]] were formed in 1972 with Smith as lead singer.{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=17}} The band recorded six studio albums for [[ABC Records]] before disbanding in 1981. In 1982, Smith signed with [[Capitol Records]] and released two albums for the label, ''Russell Smith'' (1982) and ''The Boy Next Door'' (1984). He later signed with [[Epic Records]] in 1988, where he released ''This Little Town'' in 1989. His highest-charting single, "I Wonder What She's Doing Tonight," peaked at number 37 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs|Hot Country Singles]] chart in 1989.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/russell-smith/chart-history/csi|title=Russell Smith - Chart History (Hot Country Songs)|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=March 27, 2022}} In 1993, Smith became the lead singer of [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] novelty group [[Run C&W]]. Smith also found success as a songwriter, penning Number One songs for [[Randy Travis]] ("[[Look Heart, No Hands]]"), [[T. Graham Brown]] ("[[Don't Go to Strangers]]"), [[Don Williams]] ("[[Heartbeat in the Darkness]]"), and [[Ricky Van Shelton]] ("[[Keep It Between the Lines]]"). In addition, he wrote "[[Big Ole Brew]]" which became a No. 4 country hit for [[Mel McDaniel]] in 1982. [[The Amazing Rhythm Aces]] reunited in 1994 and continued to record and tour until Smith died on July 12, 2019, at age 70, following a cancer diagnosis.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/russell-smith-amazing-rhythm-aces-dead-obituary-858738/|title=Russell Smith, Amazing Rhythm Aces Singer, Dead at 70|first1=Stephen L.|last1=Betts|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=July 14, 2019|access-date=May 12, 2020}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:20em;"| Album !
